adjectives.description: disquiet (comparative more disquiet, superlative most disquiet)

entries.meaning: (chiefly obsolete) Deprived of quiet; impatient, restless, uneasy.
examples: How rare is it for men to get their lot in the world brought up to their deſire? but are ſtill at ſome jar with their preſent condition, ſo that oft there needs no more to turn men discontent but the thought of ſome lot, which they apprehend more ſatiſfying than their own, the want whereof turns them more diſquiet than all their enjoyments are pleaſing;  […]

entries.meaning: Lack of quiet; absence of tranquility in body or mind

verbs.description: disquiet (third-person singular simple present disquiets, present participle disquieting, simple past and past participle disquieted)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To make (someone or something) worried or anxious.
examples: He felt disquieted by the lack of interest the child had shown.
